The film was the third and final Fantastic Four film to be distributed by 20th Century Fox. This indicates that 'The film' refers to the movie series 'Fantastic Four'. The distribution of these films by 20th Century Fox further supports this relationship.

After the first film's failure, a sequel scheduled for release on June 9, 2017 was canceled. This suggests that Disney played a role in the cancellation of the sequel, since they acquired 20th Century Fox in 2019.

Reed Richards and Ben Grimm have worked together on a prototype teleporter since youth. This implies that these two characters have collaborated for an extended period of time and are related through their joint work.
Reed was recruited to join Professor Franklin Storm's research institute, the Baxter Foundation. This indicates that Reed and Storm have a professional relationship.
Storm's children, scientist Sue Storm and engineer Johnny Storm, were working on completing the 'Quantum Gate'. This suggests that the 'Quantum Gate' is related to Sue and Johnny Storm's work.
Storm's protégé Victor Von Doom designed the 'Quantum Gate'. This implies that Von Doom is associated with the creation of this device.

Young prodigies were recruited into completing a 'Quantum Gate' designed by Storm's protégé Victor Von Doom at the Baxter Foundation, which is a government-sponsored research institute. This highlights that Fantastic Four members were associated with the Baxter Foundation.

Another reboot, titled The Fantastic Four: First Steps, is scheduled for release on July 25, 2025, as the first film in Phase Six of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. This suggests that 'The Fantastic Four: First Steps' is related to the Marvel Cinematic Universe franchise.
The experiment is successful, and the facility's supervisor, Dr. Allen, plans to send a group from NASA to venture into a parallel dimension known as 'Planet Zero'.

Victor attempts to touch the green lava-like substance, causing the ground they are standing on to erupt. Reed, Johnny and Ben return to their shuttle just as Sue brings them back to Earth and Victor is seemingly killed after he falls into the collapsing landscape.

Victor attempts to touch the green lava-like substance, causing the ground they are standing on to erupt. Reed, Johnny and Ben return to their shuttle just as Sue brings them back to Earth and Victor is seemingly killed after he falls into the collapsing landscape.

The Quantum Gate explodes, altering Reed, Sue, Johnny and Ben on a genetic level and granting them superhuman abilities beyond their control: Reed can stretch like rubber, Sue can become invisible and generate force fields, Johnny can engulf his entire body in fire and fly, and Ben acquires a rock-like hide which gives him superhuman strength and durability.
They are then placed in government custody to be studied and have their abilities tested.
Blaming himself for the accident, Reed escapes from the facility and tries to find a cure for their changes.

Trank posted a message on Twitter one day prior to the film's release that criticized the finished film. Expressing dissatisfaction towards the final product, he stated, "A year ago I had a fantastic version of this. And it would've received great reviews. You'll probably never see it. That's reality though."
deleted the message shortly after.
conversely stated, "I tell you, the honest truth is [Trank] did cut a great film that you'll never see. That is a shame. A much darker version, and you'll never see it."

In January 2015, Marco Beltrami was hired to compose the film's score.
Philip Glass was also hired to work on the score with Beltrami.
Additional music contributions were made by Miles Hankins, Brandon Roberts, Marcus Trumpp, and Buck Sanders, with American hip-hop recording artist El-P scoring the end credits of the film.

Kim Nam-joon, known as RM of the K-pop group BTS, and American recording artist Mandy Ventrice, worked on the digital single "Fantastic", which was released alongside the South Korean run of the film.
Beltrami described the score as "eery" and "mysterious", landing it in a "musical territory leaning towards fantasy."
In spite of the film's extremely negative reception, the soundtrack still garnered a positive response.

The teaser trailer for Fantastic Four was released in January 2015 with a generally positive response. Graeme McMillan of The Hollywood Reporter called the trailer a 'surprisingly strong step in the right direction for a faithful adaptation of an often-problematic property.'

Correspondents for Newsarama noted that there was 'nothing' in the trailer to characterize it as being based on the Fantastic Four, feeling it could have easily been a substitute for similar science fiction films such as 2014’s Interstellar.

The teaser trailer for Fantastic Four, released in January 2015, became the most-watched trailer in 20th Century Fox's history, surpassing the previous record-holder, 2014’s X-Men: Days of Future Past.
The second trailer for the film was released in April 2015. Sean O'Connell of CinemaBlend called the trailer 'amazing' and said that it 'does a much better job of setting up everyone’s roles.'
Drew McWeeny of HitFix said the film 'looks like it was approached with serious intent' and that the scale 'feels positively intimate.'
In the same month, the cast attended CinemaCon to present footage from the film, which also generated positive reviews.
The world premiere of Fantastic Four was held at Williamsburg Cinemas in New York City on August 4, 2015.
Fantastic Four was released in North America on August 7, 2015, on 3,995 screens.
In December 2012, Fantastic Four was scheduled for March 6, 2015 release.
However, this release date was changed to June 19, 2015 in November 2013.
Eventually, Fantastic Four was released on August 7, 2015.

node_2: lowest openings for a big-budget superhero movie

I have never seen a confluence of events impact the opening of a movie so swiftly," referring to negative reviews and a renegade tweet by Trank that blamed the studio for the poor reviews.

Stan Lee's statement about wanting to return all of Marvel's characters, including the Fantastic Four, to Marvel Studios implies a potential relationship between the Fantastic Four and the MCU. In December 2017, Marvel Studios' parent company, The Walt Disney Company, agreed to acquire 20th Century Fox's parent company, 21st Century Fox. As a result of this merger, which was completed by March 20, 2019, the film rights for the Fantastic Four reverted to Marvel Studios, and it was announced at the 2019 Marvel Studios San Diego Comic-Con Hall H presentation that a Fantastic Four film set in the MCU is in development.
